title: Thursday, 9th February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Hi there

PM11:00am

Guess i should have said spoiler alert or something

PM11:01am

Was just reading this interesting piece from Arash

11:01 am
PM11:01am

https://www.ft.com...-ba01-119a44939bb6

PM11:01am

The former head of JPMorgan Cazenove, Tim Wise, is reinventing himself as a boutique banker, joining former colleague Sir Simon Robertson’s tiny advisory firm.

Tim Wise, who succeeded City legend David Mayhew at the helm of Cazenove in 2011, retired from the group last year.

He has now joined Simon Robertson Associates, a firm that is as discreet as it is small. Based in a small Georgian terrace in St James’s, it boasts only half a dozen clients. Aside from a handful of support staff, Sir Simon has until now worked alone.

PM11:01am

Tim Wise

11:01 am
PM11:02am

I'd like to say 'Let's have Tim as our pic of the day'

PM11:02am

But I can't find one.

PM11:02am

In fact I don't think there's a pic of him on the entire world wide web

11:02 am
PM11:02am

But then i can't look for toffee

PM11:03am

You'll have to make do with Sir Simon

PM11:03am

11:03 am
PM11:03am

PM11:04am

Sat there in St James, all alone, trying to drum up advisory business

undefined
11:04 am
PM11:04am

Actually, talking about sad things

PM11:04am

How about sad readers?

PM11:04am

Have a look at this comment http://on.ft.com/2kROsBB

On Hannah Kuchler's lovely piece on Venmo

PM11:05am

odd bits payment system

undefined
11:05 am
PM11:05am

Think i can keep this going for an hour Bryce?

PM11:06am

No, I wont

BE11:06am

We may have no option. It's thin out there.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

There's nothing much by any standards, but for a Thursday it's just woeful. It's not half-term yet, is it? That's next week, isn't it?

BE11:07am

Could we fill the time with Brexit stuff?

PM11:07am

Dunno

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Sure

PM11:07am

Here's a lump of Citi

PM11:07am

UK: Lower House endorses Article 50 activation – With a big majority of 494 to 122, MPs passed the European Union (Notice of Withdrawal) Act authorizing the government to trigger Article 50 TEU and begin the process of leaving the EU. After the government published a White Paper outlining its negotiation objectives and promised Parliament a vote before it signs off on a deal and thus ratification on the EU side begins, the bill passed without amendment. The Scottish National Party, the Liberal Democrats and a minority of 52 Labour MPs voted against the bill. It will now go to the House of Lords, where it can also be amended or rejected. The second reading in the Upper House is scheduled for 20/21 February, followed by the Committee Stage on 27 February and 1 March and the Third Reading on 7 March, just before the Chancellor’s budget on 8 March. In the event that the Upper House, where the government does not have a majority, makes amendments, the bill would have to return to the Lower House, where the government could try to overturn them. Readings in the Lower House would begin on 13 March. Comment: The passage of the bill shows that the Conservative Party remains strongly united behind Prime Minister May and her government and sets a strong precedent for the House of Lords. The likelihood of early elections has further diminished and the Brexit timeline of the government to trigger Article 50 TEU by 31 March is intact.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

But I'm so bored of Brexit. There clearly so much work involved that there's no room for the government to do anything else

PM11:08am

For the foreseeable

BE11:09am

Wasn't that put as an argument in favour? As in, it'll paralyse Parliament, which tends to be a good thing.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Not sure I agree with that

BE11:10am

Well, no. I only said "an argument" .... It's not my argument, nor a remotely sensible one. But if there are straws needing grasped, it might be considered a straw.

BE11:10am

Anyway.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Yeah anyway

undefined
PM11:10am

There are bits of strategy around

11:10 am
PM11:11am

Garthwaite at Credit Suisse has fresh stuff out

PM11:11am

Let me share the cover page

PM11:11am

Usual place the rest

11:11 am
PM11:11am

This report was published on 9 February 2017 at 05:04:13 AM UTC. The biggest debate concerns how long the reflation trade will continue: Having completed an extensive round of marketing in the US and Europe, we note that many clients believe we are early cycle and thus want to stick to being overweight cyclicals. We disagree: labour market tightness in the US, UK, Japan and China is characteristic of a later-cycle phase. In general, the reflation trades, manifesting in value vs growth and cyclicals vs defensives, continue to be seen as plays on higher yields. Clients remain bearish on bonds, but see only a small rise in bond yields from here. In our view, the risk is that bond yields rise more than the consensus expects (remembering that US yields hit 3.0% during the taper tantrum), and thus financials continue to outperform. Non-financial cyclicals have, by contrast, priced in a US bond yield of c.3% (see our recent piece Four areas of complacency). The consensus is very long the dollar (which looks vulnerable on a 12- to 18-month view, in our opinion) and modestly bullish on global GDP growth and equities.

PM11:11am

Regions: The consensus is overweight on Japan (though foreigners, the swing investor, have bought for only 4 months compared with their normal period of buying at 28 months). Clients have been adding to Continental Europe, but are still underweight, in our judgement. Worries over political risk remain dominant. Investors are much more cautious on GEM given dollar views and concerns over protectionism. We believe that GEM should be more resilient to higher US rates/a stronger dollar because of the sharp improvement in their basic balance of payments deficits, while the sector-adjusted P/E is now at a 20% discount to developed markets, a 12-year low. China appears to have fallen off investors' radar screens for now, with questions in only one out of five meetings, and that is despite a sharp rise in government bond yields. We came across no clients who feared a meaningful slowdown ahead of the 19th Party Congress.

PM11:11am

Trump: This came up at virtually every meeting in Europe and more than we expected in the US: there is little consensus. Moreover, well informed US funds seemed to have diverging views on the issues, especially on the implementation of the border adjustment tax, suggesting any major changes have not been discounted (with WTI/Brent being the consensus border adjustment tax trade). Our 'Trump trades' have been: defence stocks, higher bond yields (and overweight of financials), Russia and Japan.

11:11 am
PM11:12am

Sectors/themes: Consensus longs among our clients included Alphabet and defence stocks (we agree with both). Consensus longs where we disagree: semis are thought to be in a super-cycle and, increasingly, investors are long of mining. Investors still appear to view financials as more of a trade/hedge (on rising bond yields) than necessarily an investment in fundamentals. European investors have clearly turned bearish on healthcare (and are skeptical of valuations because the sector is over-earning), though we had almost no questions in the US. Most clients see oil capped at $55-60pb by shale.

PM11:12am

done

PM11:12am

Actually I might mention that I put a v interesting longer read up in the LR earlier

11:12 am
PM11:12am

I'm not going to say what it is

PM11:12am

Cos this is a public bit of AV, while the LR is private -- not google indexed

PM11:13am

Wink smile

11:12 am
undefined
BE11:13am

Should we move onto corporate ............?

PM11:13am

guess so

11:13 am
BE11:14am

RPC seems to have followers.

RPC Group PLC (RPC:LSE): Last: 1,000, down 59.5 (-5.62%), High: 1,091, Low: 997.00, Volume: 1.63m
BE11:14am

Big US expansion on the tape this morning.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Letica Group. Paying £391m, or £511m if it all goes right.

PM11:15am

hmm

PM11:15am

( equity strategy in the usual place now - https://ftalphavil...room/content/71005 )

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Financed by a 1 for 4 underwritten rights issue of £552m, so they're assuming it all goes right.

BE11:16am

(The spare of that is to pay down debt.)

BE11:16am

It's expensive. 8.5x EV/EBITDA

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Though about in linw with RPC itself, which is 8.6x forward EV/EBITDA

BE11:17am

Let me get UBS to summarise the logic.

BE11:17am

We believe this deal will double RPC's presence in the Americas which is in line with company's strategy to expand outside Europe. With the rights issue, we expect this deal to be marginally dilutive to earnings in the short term.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Leticia is a leading North American manufacturer and distributor of rigid plastic packaging and foodservice products with sales of $450m (£359m) and EBITDA of $57m (£46m) as of last financial year. The company expects purchasing synergies of $5m and additional cost savings of $12m to be realised within a 24 month frame. We believe this will add c.10% to the Group EBIT for FY2017/18E.

BE11:17am

RPC also reported an in-line trading for the third quarter with continued good organic growth with the adjusted operating profit ahead of management's expectations driven by early realisation of the GCS and BPI synergies.

BE11:18am

Our price target of 1,300p is based on our base-case DCF analysis and implies an EV/EBITA of 14.0x and a PE pf 16.5x for CY18E on our estimates. Today's acquisition confirms our view of RPC becoming the global #2 in plastic packaging as it successfully executes on its strategy to consolidate the market. We expect to see small underlying upgrades on consensus estimates on the back of today's trading statement.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And Jefferies.

BE11:18am

RPC expect Letica acquisition to deliver pre-tax cost synergies of at least US$5m p.a. within the second full financial year of ownership, from cost reductions, principally through polymer purchasing optimisation, distribution and logistics optimisation using Letica’s truck business, the elimination of duplicate head office costs and other functions, efficiency savings and transfer of best practices. Additionally, Letica management has identified approximately US$12m p.a. of incremental cost savings opportunities.

BE11:18am

RPC expect Letica acquisition and rights issue to enhance
RPC earnings per share in the first full financial year post completion with Letica’s ROCE ahead of RPC’s WACC. Letica’s RONOA and RoS were more than 20% and more than 10%, respectively, for the financial year ended 30 June 2016.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

RPC revenues in the third quarter of the financial year ending 31
March 2017 increased significantly compared to the same period last year. The adjusted operating profit for the period was significantly ahead of last year and also better than management’s expectations, benefiting from organic growth, the contribution of acquisitions, realisation of synergies, the easing of the polymer price headwind as well as a foreign exchange translation benefit. The GCS and BPI businesses continued to perform well with acquisition-related synergies in line with expectations, and the Group achieved good cash flow development in the period. The fourth quarter of the financial year ending 31 March 2017 has started well.

BE11:19am

Since 30 September 2016, RPC has acquired or agreed to
acquire, six companies for an aggregate enterprise value of approximately £460m. The combined consideration for these acquisitions and the upfront consideration for Letica is approximately £850m. The Rights Issue will be used to satisfy part of the consideration for these acquisitions and allow RPC to repay existing debt following the completion of the other recent acquisitions to target a leverage of approximately 2.1x Net debt/EBITDA.

PM11:19am

Hmm -- we should note that Jefferies are one of the underwriters

11:19 am
PM11:19am

What's the rights at? 665p?

PM11:20am

The Rights Issue has been fully underwritten by Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch ("Deutsche Bank"), Jefferies International Limited ("Jefferies") and Merrill Lynch International ("BofA Merrill Lynch") (together, the "Underwriters"), and is not subject to shareholder approval.

PM11:20am

Taking on lots of risk there

11:20 am
PM11:20am

not

PM11:20am

Wouldnt be surprised if Mr N Collins has something to say about that on Saturday

PM11:21am

Details here btw http://www.investe...1702090700104219W/

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Hm. I'm not that excited by the "money for nothing" underwriting thing.

BE11:22am

Yes, of course, they're wearing no risk at an issue price of 665p.

PM11:22am

When was the last time you saw equity underwriters wearing the stick tho?

11:22 am
BE11:22am

StanChart?

PM11:22am

Oh yeah

BE11:22am

(And one does wonder if they tweaked the issue price down from 666p, for satanic reasons?)

11:22 am
PM11:22am

maybe!

BE11:23am

There's a tradeoff though -- between pricing very low which keeps the underwriting fees minimal, and pricing very low to make underwriting irrelevant.

BE11:23am

I don't know where to draw the line in that tradeoff. Because I just type for a living.

11:23 am
PM11:24am

Thing is, with underwriting it's just like a service charge. They should auction the job -- see who will underwrite at the tightest margin

PM11:24am

But whatever

PM11:24am

You are right. it's boring

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Oh, I should say that I also cut and paste. Here's Numis:

BE11:24am

In spite of the valuation multiple implied by the initial consideration for today's transaction, we believe the market will see the strategic value in the deal. Accompanying today’s acquisition is a positive update for Q3, highlighting that adj. EBIT for the period has been better than management’s expectations and Q4 has started well. Ahead of upgrades to our estimates, we remain happy to maintain our ADD recommendation and 1200p target price.

undefined
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Otherwise in corporate .............. Tate mentioned.

Tate & Lyle PLC (TATE:LSE): Last: 709.00, down 11.5 (-1.60%), High: 748.00, Low: 708.50, Volume: 1.41m
BE11:26am

The ingredients company that's absolutely not a sugar company, though is sometimes a sweetener company.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Though really, it's a bulk corn milling company.

BE11:26am

Trading's fine!

BE11:27am

Charlie Mills at Credit Suisse is, of course, Mr US Corn Wet Milling.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Here's his summary.

BE11:28am

■ Q3 update: the group is trading a little ahead of expectations, we raise our EPS estimate by 4%.
■ Three items lead to our upgrade; In order of magnitude they are Commodities, US sweeteners and Sucralose.
■ Commodities (largely ethanol and by-products) look set to break even (we had a modest loss), with ethanol a bit better in the quarter (but has edged back since), and by-product prices holding up.
■ In US Sweeteners the group confirms the comments from peers that modest margin gains were achieved in the annual negotiations, while volumes remain "robust".
■ Sucralose has seen weaker pricing but perhaps not quite as severe as might have been expected and the benefits of consolidating the two production sites into one means Q3 profits are slightly up (we had small down).
■ The sum of the above means an upgrade in our EPS estimates this year of 4%, though we note in general these increases are in the lower valued/cyclical parts of the business (Bulk), so no change in our price target.
■ On a calendar basis T&L trades on 14.6x 2017E earnings, versus ADM (14.5x) and Ingredion 15.3x.

PM11:29am

Can I ask a stupid question?

11:00 am
PM11:00am

Welcome to a thin pickings session of Markets Live

PM11:29am

Why is Tate so sensitive about producing sugar?

PM11:29am

Cos it does supply sugar

11:29 am
PM11:30am

But I was just reading through their website -- adn there's no sugar to be found, anywhere

BE11:30am

There's sugar refining business which I thought was exited in 2010.

PM11:30am

But the Tate brand still sits on sugar in supermarkets

11:30 am
PM11:31am

Unless im going mad

BE11:31am

Yes, indeed. I'm not entirely sure why there are still bags in Tesco that say "Tate & Lyle" ...... Nor why you can still buy tins of that stuff with T&L above the dead lion being eaten by bees.

PM11:31am

11:34 am
PM11:34am

We are suffering from web problems

PM11:34am

Bear with us

BE11:34am

Back now!

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Anyway, just wanted to say management has spent a long time hosting seminars and such about its specialist ingredients business, which is higher margin. But it remains a corn milling business.

undefined
BE11:35am

@chopper: no.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

At least, nothing we can put in print.

BE11:36am

There really is nothing worse than the "PE looking at xx" rumour, because that's what PE does, all the time.

BE11:37am

There's some more specific stuff going around with regards Capita -- which is less than £4bn these days, remember, though EV rather bigger -- but putting it here or anywhere would be irresponsible so we won't.

11:37 am
undefined
PM11:38am

Few people seemingly caught off guard by Ashmore

PM11:38am

Interims here http://www.investe...1702090700083903W/

11:38 am
BE11:38am

It's a beat! It's a huge beat, in fact.

PM11:39am

It's a huge beat out of leftfield

PM11:39am

Though EM was supposed to be a generalised mess

11:39 am
Ashmore Group PLC (ASHM:LSE): Last: 338.50, up 19.5 (+6.11%), High: 342.80, Low: 329.80, Volume: 1.84m
BE11:40am

But it's the kind of wide beat margin that suggests, rather than any kind of operational outperformance, that the company's numbers can't really be compared like-for-like with the analysts' numbers.

PM11:40am

oh, right

11:40 am
BE11:40am

And remember, Ashmore's already put out its end 2016 AUM.

BE11:41am

What we have here is a consensus failure of calculation, arguably.

BE11:41am

I'll let RBC throw some numbers at you.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Adjusted net revenue: £135.7MM vs RBC of £131.8MM consensus: £128.3MM); management fees were a small miss to our expectations at £114.9MM (RBC: £116.8MM, but ahead of consensus at £111.5MM), while performance fees significantly exceeded both RBC and consensus expectations at £21.6MM (RBC: £12.5MM; consensus: £8.8MM).

BE11:42am

Adjusted EBITDA: £89.7MM vs RBC of £83.1MM (consensus:
£77.3MM); the beat was driven by both higher net revenue and lower-than-anticipated operating expenses of £46.0MM (RBC: £48.8MM).

• Adjusted PBT: £99.9MM vs RBC of £90.6MM (consensus: £85.0MM); including FX effects, Ashmore’s PBT was £121.5MM.

• Diluted EPS: 13.9p vs RBC of 10.2p (consensus: 9.3p), with the large beat being driven by higher-than-expected net revenue, lower-than- forecasted operating expenses, seed capital gains, and FX effects.

• Interim dividend: 4.55p vs both RBC and consensus of 4.55p.

• Ashmore had net cash of £378.1MM as at 31-Dec-16, above our
£347.1MM forecast, and a blended fee margin in H1/17 of 54bps, a 3bps decline y/y and 1bp below our expectation. We already forecast an ongoing decline in the blended fee margin.

BE11:42am

Ashmore indicates that “investor sentiment towards Emerging
Markets continues to improve,” and that its “active investment processes” are “delivering strong investment performance across [the] fund range.” 91% of Ashmore’s AUM is outperforming benchmarks over one year, while 81% is outperforming over three years (30 June 2016: 69% and 63%, respectively). The company indicates that the US election outcome that “interrupted the improvement in sentiment towards Emerging Markets ... has been short-lived with asset prices strengthening into 2017.”

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Today’s results are hard to fault on any measure, and will put
further upward pressure on the share price in our opinion, despite its 13% increase so far in 2017. The results will also help to alleviate concerns about Ashmore’s premium valuation. We forecast FY17E diluted EPS of 19.8p versus consensus of 18.3p. Material consensus upgrades should follow from today’s results and Ashmore’s outlook. Capping Ashmore’s upside is its valuation, as Ashmore trades at the highest premium of any asset managers we cover, at 11.7x CY17E EBITDA (sector average: 9.2x) and at 16.5x CY17E EPS (sector average: 13.3x).

BE11:43am

And Barclays, which does a pretty good teardown of the quality of the beat rather than the size.

BE11:43am

Ashmore reported management fees of £115m, +16% yoy, vs AUM up +6% over the same period. This is a 8% beat vs our forecast of £106.4m and 3% vs company-collected consensus of £111.5m. Revenue margin of 54 bps compared to 56bps for FY16 and 57bps at H1 16, but was more than offset by favourable FX translation effects. The statement detailed margin attrition particularly in External Debt, Local Currency and Equities buckets, whilst Corporate Debt margin improved, and Alternatives and Blended Debt were stable. Net revenues of £144m is a 12% beat versus us and consensus estimate of £128m, driven by much higher performance fees than expected of £21.8m vs our forecast of £6.0m and consensus expectations of £8.8m.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Underlying costs were broadly in line at £49.1m vs consensus' £48.9mm and a little better than our forecast of £51.5m. Adjusted EBITDA of £90m is 14-16% of consensus £77.6m and Barclays forecast of £79m, driven by the revenue beat. Underlying PBT of £100m is up 75% yoy. This was a 18% beat vs consensus of £85m, driven by top line as well as an unexpected seed capital gain of £25.8m. At the bottom line, diluted EPS of 13.9p is 42% above consensus' 9.3p and more than doubled yoy from 6.5p. A flat interim DPS of 4.55p was in line with our and consensus expectations.

BE11:44am

At the bottom line, 1H17 EPS of 13.9p is more than enough to ensure likelihood of FY17 DPS being covered (Barc FY17E DPS f/c 16.65p) which is likely to reassure investors. Management's outlook is quite bullish, saying investment sentiment towards EM continues to improve, with the disruption caused by the US election short-lived with asset prices strengthening into 2017. They believe there will be further strong performance in 2017 and a return to the improving flow trend seen for most of 2016. They cited Ashmore’s strong performance track record, diversification and expertise of country-exposure, low investor allocation to EM Shares and a more dovish Fed as defensive factors against the risk of strengthening USD and Trump’s protectionist policy stance. ASHM has outperformed ytd up 13% vs FTSE 250 +3%. Valuation at 19x 2017E PE vs the sector average of 13.5x, with a 5.5% yield.

BE11:45am

So, AUM is what it is. Clients hit for a surprising amount of performance fees, plus a sizable FX tailwind.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

And management reckon it's all going to turn out fine. On 19x forward. Up to you, I guess.

undefined
PM11:46am

Thanks for all that

11:46 am
PM11:46am

We're getting through

PM11:46am

Frontier Developments p interims here

PM11:46am

http://www.investe...1702090700083904W/

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Frontier Developments PLC (FDEV:LSE): Last: 285.00, up 2.5 (+0.88%), High: 275.00, Low: 275.00, Volume: 8.09k
PM11:47am

11:47 am

I preferred Eidos. When I worked at a wire, Eidos used to send me review copies of their new releases.

BE11:47am

Which I'd take down to CEX and sell for £20 a pop.

PM11:48am

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Sending me, a financial wire hack at a third-rate agency, review copies of Tomb Raider is a small but potentially significant indicator of this profligacy.

PM11:50am

We've allowed ourselves to become rubbish at tapping freebies

PM11:50am

Too professional -- and all the while trust in journalism has collapsed

11:50 am
PM11:50am

World upside down

PM11:50am

People don't understand that financial journalism used to be terribly corrupt

BE11:51am

Hm. Charles Stanley still send me a diary every year.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

And every year they include a note about when, in 2009 I think it was, Neil Hume suggested the diaries were "plastic-y".

PM11:51am

There's a Thomson Reuters calendar in the post basket -- addressed to you. You havent even bothered to throw it away

PM11:52am

Been there for two months

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Oh! Is it illustrated with screenshots from Eikon? I rather want a Thomson Reuters calendar and am excited by this development.

BE11:53am

Anyway. Perhaps we should go back to doing something more relevant to the readers' interests.

undefined
11:53 am
PM11:53am

Like what?

BE11:53am

... well, yes. I've made a rod for my own back there, haven't I?

BE11:54am

@BlueHorseshoe mentioned S&N

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Which I'd guess is in every punter's pre-event M&A basket, and has been for approximately 20 years.

Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,170, down 31 (-2.58%), High: 1,177, Low: 1,143, Volume: 2.45m
BE11:55am

Results tell us very little, really.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Q4's in line, more or less.

PM11:55am

(OJatHome -- that was the chap. Dunno what happened to him)

BE11:55am

Guidance reasonable rather than exciting.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Headline shows revenue down 1% but that's an effect of fewer trading days rather than people having ...... um ...... fewer hips. Dunno.

BE11:56am

Here's Caz.

BE11:56am

Smith & Nephew has reported FY16 results in the lower half of consensus expectations for revenues and at the bottom of the range for EBITA. A lower than expected tax rate means adjusted EPS came in line. The focus will be on the FY17 guidance, which is unusually precise by S&N’s standards, with ‘hard’ guidance for revenue growth and EBITA margins. The middle of this range implies a c2% cut to consensus, but we believe consensus may also have under-estimated the rebound in the tax rate (this year’s rate was flattered by one-offs). We expect more colour on the call around below the line items, but our initial thoughts are for FY17 consensus downgrades in the mid-single digits and similar falls in the share price (possibly slightly more given the limited short interest).

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Unusually for S&N, the company is issuing quantitative guidance. Underlying revenue growth is expected to accelerate to 3-4%, but FX is expected to shave c100bp off this and the GYN disposal a further 80bp, leaving expected reported revenue growth of 1.2-2.2%. This implies revenues of $4,725-4,771m vs consensus at $4,822m. The middle of the range implies a 1.6% downgrade. EBITA margins are expected to improve 20-70bp (from 21.8%). We assume the company will achieve the low end of the margin range at the low end of the revenue range, and operating leverage from higher top line growth would drive margins to the high end of the range. This implies an EBITA range of $1,040-1,073m; Consensus is at $1,077m. The middle of the guidance range implies a c2% cut to consensus. However, as we set out in our preview (here), we believe consensus is mis-modelling the tax rate (and possibly interest), and we could therefore see higher cuts to EPSa. We expect more detail with the ‘technical guidance’ at the presentation.

BE11:57am

The shares have bounced c13% from the lows in November (post Q3 results), but we expect a further round of downgrades to weigh on the shares in the near term. The shares trade on 16.9x FY17 on current consensus forecasts, but mid-single digit downgrades would imply 17.7x. We expect both downgrades and a little multiple compression could see the shares nearer the £11 than the £12 level in the short term.

BE11:57am

And MOST.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

2H FY16 result was a slight consensus miss driven by a weaker top line and margins. Our investment thesis for 2017 is based on an acceleration in organic sales growth and margin inflection and the company guidance suggests that 2017 should be a better year compared to 2016. We highlighted earlier that the 2H FY16 result was a hurdle that the company had to cross, as a result of fewer selling days (especially Q4 which had 4 less trading days), which would materially impact sales growth and profitability. Although we have +3.1% organic sales growth dialled in for FY17E vs. company guidance of +3-4%, we feel there is scope for the company to come-out at the upper end of the range, helped by a recovery in China and launch of its next generation Renaysis product in Negative Pressure Wound Therapy. We have an Overweight rating with a PT of £13.01.

And that's that.
